title: Wave Equation
text:
The wave equation is a hyperbolic PDE that describes the propagation of waves through space.


\[\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = c^2 \nabla^2 u\]
where \(u\) is displacement, \(c\) is wave speed, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the wave equation: - Finite Domain (Standing Waves) - 1D String (Separation of Variables) - 2D Membrane (Separation of Variables in Polar/Cartesian) - Infinite Domain (Traveling Waves) - 1D (D’Alembert’s Formula) - 2D (Method of Descent / Poisson) - 3D (Kirchhoff’s Formula)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Wave Equation
text:
The wave equation is a hyperbolic PDE that describes the propagation of waves through space.


\[\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = c^2 \nabla^2 u\]
where \(u\) is displacement, \(c\) is wave speed, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the wave equation: - Finite Domain (Standing Waves) - 1D String (Separation of Variables) - 2D Membrane (Separation of Variables in Polar/Cartesian) - Infinite Domain (Traveling Waves) - 1D (D’Alembert’s Formula) - 2D (Method of Descent / Poisson) - 3D (Kirchhoff’s Formula)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Poisson Equation
text:
The Poisson equation is an elliptic PDE that extends the Laplace equation to include a source term.


\[\nabla^2 u = f\]
where \(u\) is a potential function, \(f\) is a source term, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the Poisson equation: - Dirichlet Boundary Conditions (Prescribed Value) - Neumann Boundary Conditions (Prescribed Derivative)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Poisson Equation
text:
The Poisson equation is an elliptic PDE that extends the Laplace equation to include a source term.


\[\nabla^2 u = f\]
where \(u\) is a potential function, \(f\) is a source term, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the Poisson equation: - Dirichlet Boundary Conditions (Prescribed Value) - Neumann Boundary Conditions (Prescribed Derivative)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Math-Viz: PDE Visualization Framework
text:
PDE Visualization Framework - A comprehensive tool for solving and visualizing Partial Differential Equations with real-time 3D rendering.

Quick Links

GitHub Repository
Live Web App
PDE Solutions & Derivations
Technical Documentation



Overview
Math-Viz provides an intuitive interface for exploring complex mathematical concepts through interactive 3D visualization.

Supported PDEs

Heat Equation (Parabolic / Time-Dependent)

Finite Domain (Bounded)
Infinite Domain (Unbounded)

Fourier Transform
Heat Kernel (Fundamental Solution)


Laplace Equation (Elliptic / Steady-State)

Cartesian (Rectangle)

Dirichlet (Prescribed Value)
Neumann (Prescribed Derivative)

Polar (Disk)

Dirichlet
Neumann


Poisson Equation (Elliptic / Steady-State)

Dirichlet Boundary Conditions
Neumann Boundary Conditions

Wave Equation (Hyperbolic / Time-Dependent)

Finite Domain (Standing Waves)

1D String (Separation of Variables)
2D Membrane (Sep. of Vars in Polar/Rect)

Infinite Domain (Traveling Waves)

1D (D’Alembert’s Formula)
2D (Method of Descent / Poisson)
3D (Kirchhoff’s Formula)

title: Noah Wotschke
text:
Mechanical Engineering Student | ETH Zurich
I am a second-year student at ETH Zurich.
This website acts as a personal archive of my work in engineering and mathematics. I use this space to document my projects—from academic research to private coding experiments. My goal is to capture the learning process and showcase the underlying logic of the systems I study.

Featured Work
Math-Viz: PDE Visualization Framework - A comprehensive tool for solving and visualizing Partial Differential Equations with real-time 3D rendering. Includes detailed mathematical derivations and numerical solution methods for heat, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.


Explore

Projects - Complete portfolio of engineering and technical projects
Extracurriculars - Involvement and activities
About - More about me and my interests

For a more detailed view of my background and interests, please visit the About section.

title: About
text: About this site

title: Heat Equation
text:
The heat equation is a fundamental parabolic partial differential equation that describes how heat diffuses through space over time.


\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \alpha \nabla^2 u\]
where \(u(x,t)\) is temperature, \(\alpha\) is thermal diffusivity, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the heat equation: - Finite Domain (Bounded) - Infinite Domain (Unbounded) - Fourier Transform - Heat Kernel (Fundamental Solution)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Heat Equation
text:
The heat equation is a fundamental parabolic partial differential equation that describes how heat diffuses through space over time.


\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \alpha \nabla^2 u\]
where \(u(x,t)\) is temperature, \(\alpha\) is thermal diffusivity, and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the heat equation: - Finite Domain (Bounded) - Infinite Domain (Unbounded) - Fourier Transform - Heat Kernel (Fundamental Solution)




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Laplace Equation
text:
The Laplace equation is an elliptic PDE that describes steady-state phenomena with no time dependence.


\[\nabla^2 u = 0\]
where \(u\) is a potential function and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the Laplace equation: - Cartesian Coordinates (Rectangle) - Dirichlet (Prescribed Value) - Neumann (Prescribed Derivative) - Polar Coordinates (Disk) - Dirichlet - Neumann




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: Laplace Equation
text:
The Laplace equation is an elliptic PDE that describes steady-state phenomena with no time dependence.


\[\nabla^2 u = 0\]
where \(u\) is a potential function and \(\nabla^2\) is the Laplacian operator.



This section covers various solutions to the Laplace equation: - Cartesian Coordinates (Rectangle) - Dirichlet (Prescribed Value) - Neumann (Prescribed Derivative) - Polar Coordinates (Disk) - Dirichlet - Neumann




Derivations - Full mathematical derivations and solution methods

title: PDE Solutions & Derivations
text:
This section contains comprehensive mathematical derivations and solutions for the key partial differential equations implemented in Math-Viz.


Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are fundamental to modeling physical phenomena across engineering, physics, and mathematics. The equations below represent the most important classes of PDEs, categorized by their mathematical properties.



Parabolic PDEs describe diffusion and heat transfer processes that evolve towards steady-state over time.
Elliptic PDEs describe steady-state phenomena where no time dependence exists.
Hyperbolic PDEs describe wave propagation and oscillatory phenomena.

title: PDE Solutions & Derivations
text:
This section contains comprehensive mathematical derivations and solutions for the key partial differential equations implemented in Math-Viz.


Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are fundamental to modeling physical phenomena across engineering, physics, and mathematics. The equations below represent the most important classes of PDEs, categorized by their mathematical properties.



Parabolic PDEs describe diffusion and heat transfer processes that evolve towards steady-state over time.
Elliptic PDEs describe steady-state phenomena where no time dependence exists.
Hyperbolic PDEs describe wave propagation and oscillatory phenomena.

title: PDE Solutions & Derivations
text:
Explore Individual PDEs

Heat Equation
Parabolic / Time-Dependent
\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \alpha \nabla^2 u\]
The heat equation describes how temperature diffuses through space over time. Explore finite and infinite domain solutions, including Fourier transform and heat kernel methods.
View Heat Equation →



Laplace Equation
Elliptic / Steady-State
\[\nabla^2 u = 0\]
The Laplace equation describes steady-state potential fields with no source term. Solutions cover both Cartesian and polar coordinate systems with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions.
View Laplace Equation →



Poisson Equation
Elliptic / Steady-State
\[\nabla^2 u = f\]
The Poisson equation extends the Laplace equation with a source term \(f\), modeling phenomena like electrostatics and gravitational fields.
View Poisson Equation →



Wave Equation
Hyperbolic / Time-Dependent
\[\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial t^2} = c^2 \nabla^2 u\]
The wave equation describes wave propagation through space and time. Solutions include standing waves in finite domains and traveling waves in infinite domains.
View Wave Equation →
